Ahh man! What a mixed bag the camera has turned out to be (for me). I have the 256GB Exynos, here's my findings on the photography front...

In general I think it's fair to say this phone expands the shooting possibilities far beyond any other device I've had to date, which most recently include the S20 FE 5G, Pixel 4XL, Pixel 2XL. For me the choice of focal ranges is what i've been looking for and something I didn't ever expect to see in a package like this. I thought triple lens cameras would be the limit, so the S21 Ultra came as a surprise and I hoped mistakes made in the past generation would be ironed out. The hardware itself is definitely more than capable of handling a multitude of shooting scenarios but it is ultimately let down by the software that I VERY much doubt will be fixed, ever!

My first impressions were of the sensor & lens choices themselves, all seem very capable, all include massively improved stabilization and autofocus capabilities and even the pixel sizes are promising particularly on the tele lenses. A clue to Samsung engineering decisions comes with the assumed improvement over to the 108MP pixel binning sensor compared to the S20 Ultra last year, but it serves far more than just taking photos in the wide setting. Samsung are clearly borrowing ideas from the AI kings at Google, but their implementation is weak and in many scenarios I have found using the cameras terribly frustrating.

Overall, in brightly lit daytime shots indoors and outdoors with all lenses I cannot complain, but that's as long as you're pointing the camera at certain targets that are deemed ideal for the lens mode you are in! When I venture outside these ideal scenarios I'm ending up with unexpected and awful results. In medium and low light scenes my problem is exacerbated further through Samsungs smart choices that you have no control over whatsoever, giving me further disappointing results.

So what am I banging on about here Well in a nutshell it's Samsungs focus assist mode. As an end user you only know it exists because you can selectively turn it off between the 0.6x UW and 1x W lenses when moving a subject much closer to the lens itself...But, you cannot turn it off between the 1x W, 3x tele and 10x tele lenses! In scenarios Sammy deem fit for telephoto shots, ie. extra long focal length scenes (generally) in good light the tele lenses are always picked at the set 3x and 10x magnifications. Pictures are often impressive but at times smoothing could be better and sometimes I get light haloing around objects, but still a big improvement on anything i've had before.

It all goes terribly wrong when I bring my subjects much closer to the lenses in either the 3x or 10x tele modes. These lenses have great autofocus and are more than capable of handling this scenario, but what the software does (after a second or two) is pick the next sodding lens down and then upscale the flaming image! Some might say, that's my fault because I've pushed the ISO or shutter speed too much, but no, it's happening when there's more than enough light available to these lenses and even if it wasn't, night mode would overcome this in dark scenes anyhow!

Which moves me onto the 108MP sensor, Sammy picked it not just for the 4x binning extra light crud. It also makes for a great cropping in option when deemed necessary, and you'd think the results would be comparable to the 3x tele, but sadly no, in almost every shot i've taken where it's used the 1x to crop in the results are still very disappointing compared to the optical lenses. Smoke and mirrors people, smoke and mirrors!

Focus assist should be optional for ALL lenses and if you do turn it off, all it needs to do is warn you that a shot might not come out as well as you expected. Although to be blunt the results with it permanently on are terrible anyway! In fact I personally feel it shouldn't be doing what it's doing at all. Anyone who has ever held a camera and taken a photograph will know these things cannot work miracles, and Samsung are literally trying to trick you into thinking it can, with awful results!

If you get the over processed, smushed images they are all coming from the lenses dropping down and upscaling or cropping in from the 108MP sensor. Utterly awful engineering decisions that make it all look seamless and magic but you more often that not get terrible photos.

The number 1 thing that turns me off these days with these high end smartphones is the manufacturers ridiculous pricing these days here in Canada. Hell no I won't ever spend $1000 or above for a smartphone, heck I wouldn't spend more than $500 for a high end smartphone. We have to remember these high end smartphones only costs these manufacturers $100 bucks to makes these smartphones from Chinese factory workers that are forced in labour factory camps as slaves.
I've literally just bought a brand new sealed Huawei P10 which is Huawei's high end model but just a few years ago for only $150 bucks and this smartphone still performs much the same as any other android device of today's market.
And I've bought a brand new sealed Google Pixel 3 for only $120 bucks as my spare device in case my P10 breaks. So I bought 2 high end smartphones for only $270 bucks. Using Kijiji marketplace is an amazing place to find cheap deals on brand new sealed smartphones. I refuse to buy smartphones at retail stores that charge over inflated prices plus I refuse to pay extra money on taxes which is a waste of money. Using Kijiji no need to pay taxes which is a big plus. I don't mind buying last year's or the year before that high end smartphones to save a ton of cash which is still a great deal. These days smartphones don't have anything really new to attract me to pay over $1000 bucks for them. Last year's phone model still can make calls, texts, takes photos just fine. Can still browse all my favourite apps just the same. If these manufacturers want my $1000 plus bucks to give them, give me a great reason I want to. Wow me with something totally technological advanced more what we have had already for years now. A smartphone is just a smartphone. I don't see anything more advanced since 2008 really. These smartphones been pretty much the same. Same rectangular shaped. Touch screen. Apps. Calling and texting. Taking photos. Nothing really that new other than adding little features to pretty much the exact same phone itself. Each year these manufacturers pretty much re-release the same phone design over and over again but add an extra cameranone year. Next year they add an extra feature. Year after that change the bodies material or add different colors. But consumers are so tricked to upgrade to the next released device that's pretty much the same phone of the year before other than 1 or 2 added features. I no longer see any wow factors anymore to convince me to spend more than $500 on a smartphone. I tend to not even want to spend more than $200 these days cause there hasn't been any huge wow factors anymore to make me blown away.
What will blow me away is if these manufacturers would invent something different all together other than the same boring smartphone we keep getting year over year since 2008.
We need a totally new invented idea all together.
I want what smartphones offer which I don't need to carry with me at all and don't need to charge at all. Something that's build and created like virtual reality goggles offer I can see through my eyes when I want to look something up. When I want to make a call I hear the call through my ears automatically without a actual device itself.
Like a special lens build into my eyes. Speaker imbedded in my ears. And it all keeps it charge by using my body as its power source.
You only need to pay a one time payment to be implanted and it's good for up to 40 years. No monthly bills.
We only need to get a upgrade after 40 years.
Now something like this would wow me and make me want to spend a huge payment. You imagine having access to the whole web , watching all movies, tv shows . Watching live sports, texting someone, video chatting with someone by just standing in front of a mirror to project your image back to someone by just seeing it through your build in eye lense like an implant. And can call someone by just thinking of that person's name and your implant just calls that person and your ears just hear them.
Something like this would be evolutionary and high tech. 24 hour 365 day 40 year full use without needing to ever charge a stupid handheld device which is so 2008 old tech.

It would make more sense to eliminate the Note series and focus on their foldable phones (possibly at a more "affordable" price). Samsung needs to do a better job at enticing people to buy the Note.

State-Sanctioned Crimes
After testifying before the China Tribunal, the China Organ Harvest Research Center (COHRC) published its own report in July 2019 based on years of research and analysis. The report stated that the ‚Äúon-demand killing of prisoners of conscience is driven by the state, run on an industrial scale and carried out by both military and civilian institutions.‚Äù

In contrast to the large number of organ transplants every year, China does not have a voluntary organ donation system in place. Chinese officials have claimed that 10,000 transplants are carried out each year in China, but researchers estimate the number to be much higher, at 60,000-100,000 annually, based on their analyses.

Forced organ harvesting is driven by lucrative profits, COHRC explained in its report. ‚ÄúData from 2007 shows that hospitals charged more than $65,000 for a kidney transplant, $130,000 for liver, and more than $150,000 for lung or heart. Desperate patients might make a high-price ‚Äòdonation‚Äô for a new organ at top-speed,‚Äù Fox News reported.

This horrific form of malpractice probably started in the 90s on a small scale but escalated quickly around the year 2000, when Falun Gong practitioners became the key source of organs.

‚ÄúChina later claimed that death row prisoners consented to donate their organs to the State to redeem themselves for the crimes they had committed against the State, a practice China claimed to have stopped in January 2015. However, the explosion of organ transplant activities in China from 2000, together with reports of thousands of transplant tourists going to China to purchase organs, suggests a larger supply of organs than could be sourced from executed criminals alone,‚Äù the Fox News report stated. It cited the Tribunal's report, ‚ÄúThe scale of the Chinese transplant industry, together with other evidence, points to the possibility that China is involved in forced organ harvesting and selling for profit organs from prisoners of conscience.‚Äù

The Tribunal confirmed that it ‚Äúhas had no evidence that the significant infrastructure associated with China‚Äôs transplantation industry has been dismantled and absent a satisfactory explanation as to the source of readily available organs concludes that forced organ harvesting continues till today.‚Äù

Grace Yin from COHRC said the Chinese government admitted less severe abuse by saying it was only happening to those awaiting capital punishment, to ‚Äúdivert attention away from the more severe issue.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe root issue still goes back to the Communist Party‚Äôs persecution of faith groups and its animosity toward groups that it perceives as threats to its ideological control,‚Äù she continued.

Olivia Enos, a senior policy analyst of Asian studies at The Heritage Foundation, said organ harvesting has long been a largely overlooked aspect of human rights abuses and has been mainly reported by the Falun Gong.

Some U.S. officials have began to pay attention to this issue. ‚ÄúIt is just so bizarre it was hard to believe. That [governments] can defile a human being like that,‚Äù Shawn Steel, California‚Äôs Republican National Committee (RNC) Member, said. ‚ÄúMedical tourism is big business; if you are wealthy, you can get the organ you need in a couple of weeks. Thousands are being sacrificed every year, and it is not being discussed.‚Äù

Earlier this year, Steel introduced a resolution to the RNC criticizing Beijing‚Äôs practice of forced organ harvesting from inmates. The resolution was unanimously adopted at the RNC conference in August.

Mourning the SD-cards! I have been using SD cards since forever, but it wasn't since the S4 I had been using it to actually extend my phones storage capabilities

My concern is this:
How will we use our pocket-super computer to transfer files on our very expensive phones? The instable, buggy and slow MTP protocol is no solution for a $1300-phone.
It was designed in the 90's and last used during the 00's for mp3-devices and old pre-smartphone "mp4-devices" - before it was brought back with the smartphones that is!

That's like having a $1500 laptop with no ports what so ever (no USB/SD/Ethernet), under the pretext that "you can simply use bluetooth or the Wifi to transfer files to your other devices".

If the SD-cards are going extinct, now is the time to bring back USB Mass Storage Mode or something that can compensate for it and replace MTP!

All these new phones are just getting bad. They're getting better, while getting worse at the same time. They're turning into money grabs. The phone is too attractive in my opinion. The pen is a joke in my opinion. Not too many people will buy it separate and use that hideous case with it. It's too expensive of an accessory as well. The cameras are gimmicks in my opinion. 90% of everyday people just take a selfie or take a photo of a fan dog or animal or some stupid food they had for dinner. These ridiculous zooms and other weird features are just so the companies can flex their muscles. Most people are very basic pic takers. Like snapping a pic of something their child did. Of people are trying to be professional photographers they just buy a high end camera. The ONLY features I look at in a new phone is screen size, battery size, chipset. When I was younger, I was all about buying the biggest newest top of the line phone 10 years ago. But now I'm all for budget. The $500-$700 phones do all the daily tasks and apps and social medias just as well as the top of the line. The gap between top of the line and low end is negligible anymore.

1st take away the headphone jack. Annoyed but fine. 2nd take away adapter. Inconvenienced but fine. 3rd taking away microSD? That‚Äôs a big NO. Why?
1. Security issues. You‚Äôll never be able to trade in your phone anymore without having to worry someone might recover erased data from your traded-in phone. Good data recovery apps such as Acronis will be able to purge all erased files. It‚Äôs the same reason why I would never sell a hard drive. With microSD, your storage is with you regardless of hardware changes.
2. Convenience. When time to switch/upgrade the phone, it will be great hassle to transfer data to the new phone. Especially if you have a lot of data stored. With microSD, all you need is to do is just swipe in the old card to the new phone, and you‚Äôll have all your data instantly. Yes this can be mitigated thru cloud storage. But no thanks. You will need to be anchored to internet connection at all time to retrieve data. Also there are places and countries where internet is less than reliable.
3. Stuck with whatever storage the phone has. With MicroSD, it is super convenience to be able to swipe in different cards. This is no more.

What Samsung is taking away vs. what new features it added has reached a point where the negatives start to outweigh the pluses. Taking away microSD is where the line is drawn, imho.

Forbes magazine published an article titled, ‚ÄúChina Killing Prisoners To Harvest Organs For Transplant: BMC Report Accuses China Of ‚ÄòFalsifying‚Äô Data‚Äù by Zak Doffman, on November 16, 2019. The article states that China's claim of using a voluntary donation system for its billion-dollar organ transplant industry had been refuted by a report published in BMC Medical Ethics. Researchers found that the Chinese government falsified and manipulated official organ transplant datasets.

The article states, ‚ÄúIn June, I reported on the China Tribunal in London, which found evidence of 'forced organ harvesting' from Chinese prisoners, including Falun Gong and Uighur Muslims. The Tribunal‚Äôs final judgment concluded that this 'forced organ harvesting has been committed for years...on a significant scale.' China has said that the practice has been outlawed, replaced with a system of voluntary donations. But a new report, published on November 14 in the BMC Medical Ethics journal, has refuted this, alleging that those claims of reform are being supported by the 'systematic falsification and manipulation of official organ transplant datasets in China.

@Darriona Whitfield I have a note 10+. I always felt the tendency to upgrade to the next however, the compromises they are making held me back... The Note 10+ came with 256 gb of space with an expandable micro sd slot plus 12 gb of ram. My phone still feels as snappy as when I bought it. Many camera features are off by default so enabling 4k 60 fps recording or 1080P 60 fps features are there as well.
I ended up using less features than I thought as a tech guy myself, but I really feel that the phone hasn't reached its peak yet for me to upgrade. Also there is super fast charging which brings your phone from 0 to 100% in 70 minutes (you get to 50% even faster).
In my case, when I look into these things, the upgrades do not merit me switching to the next phone. I am still happy with my purchase.

My wife is least bothered to get into the things happening in and around my family, she is reluctant and doesn't care about anything happening around her, she only cares for her and won't even stand by my side to give the moral support at least..
Without my support, my mother and sister couldn't survive.
Each and everyday I'm getting awaken at midnight and couldn't continue the sleep. There are countless number of sleepless nights..
I used to belive in God, but not anymore. Now I'm feeling like ending myself.
Only because of my mother and sister, and in order to look after their well-being I have been moving forward.
And I don't know till how long it goes on like this..

Whose condition is worse between us both?

Anyway, I don't know the exact situation you were in.
I could only wish you good luck..
Take care

After years of buying the Note series I moved off the high end and bought the Note 10 Lite. I cannot live without a headphone jack (yes, I have the Samsung Buds). Wireless earbuds are a pain to deal with and overpriced. But what really bothers me is the lack of dual sim, expandable storage.

So I live without the premium screen. My screen is fine. And I get expandable storage, dual sim, 4 camera (back), 1 camera (front). The front selfie cam isn't wide enough angle. No wireless charging but with a 25 watt charger that goes 0% - 50% easily in 30 minutes, who needs one?

As Samsung keeps stripping away everything that made them the ultimate phone while jacking prices and reducing features, it leaves those of us who still love Samsung features like Secure Folder no option but to buy their mid-range phones. I spent $375 for the Note 10 Lite. Clearly this isn't a cost cutting move when all these removed features are available in their own product line for 25% the cost (ok, list price is higher but I buy on auction sites and get the same phone brand new for much cheaper) that includes those features.

I don't understand their logic. The Note was always the best phone in the world. And as they continue to make their higher end phones plastic with no MicroSD, no dual SIM (except for the Ultra Models), no headphone jack. The logic escapes me. If they start doing this in their mid-range models, then they'll lose me forever. They clearly are hands down the most capable company to produce a beast of a phone. But I'm not paying $1,500 (Note series) for something I can get close to from their very own product line for $375 (on "that" big auction site). What will they do next, remove the charger in box?

So the Samsung/ Android architecture decides to use the expansion storage not  to its full potential, and the problem is it's removable whether by customer or from an extreme impact, so in addition as a safe guard to the device, only sacrificial data is stored on the micro SD card.

Why do people care that much about the resolution being so insane and the refresh being so high? Anybody spending more than 3 hours a day on their phone needs to get a life. I will make an exception for those using it for actual utility like music production, photo editing, or...well I guess that's it. But then, if that's the case you should be getting an iPad Pro for either of those anyways. It's so dumb people care about things like resolution/refresh rate being on par with a television. But like I said, people need to get a life if they're using their phone for more than 3 hours a day using social media (which now is for the stupid kids...Twitter is garbage to the extreme...no one gives a shit about your day). Phones are meant to used for texting, ordering food/products (Amazon/Target/etc.), and phone calls...go figure! There is a reason why when I was growing up you didn't get a phone until you had your license and a car so your parents could reach you. I stopped using my phone for anything but ordering food/products, texting, music, and calling. Once in a while I'll use it for like a slot machine game while waiting in a lobby, like for an appointment....but I decided to disconnect from the social media world completely. I realized I was an adult (I'm 35) and don't need to be doing things that the stupid kids beneath my generation are doing.

Using Twitter is for morons that think they're lives are important and others need to know about it. If you're hanging out with your friends (IN PERSON...as that is what it means to have friends, not ONLINE...) you should never be pulling out your phone to do anything. When I hang out with anyone I make sure not to pull my phone out and start texting or doing bullshit stuff. The last parties I went to in my early 30's I stopped using it completely unless it was for pictures and responding to people coming to the party. But ya, it's so funny how sad kids are these days, glued to their phones spending 5, 6, 7, or more hours on their phones. Guess that's all the dumb kids know though since they grew up with technology. The generation after mine (and the one after that) are the stupid generation, they're unable to find answers themselves and have to look up everything on the internet....then act like it's fact, and refuse to accept their wrong when told otherwise with actual factual data from books/credible sources. Oh well, at this rate the world will be done in a few decades, and I laugh at all the dumb kids that will never know how good the world was before all this shit came out.

@UnkownMan what if the quality on these phones is already the high quality that most people want? Not everyone is a pro photographer/videographer. With the increase in specs over the years, the quality of photos/videos that you can take on phones have jumped so much.

Asking people to get a camera instead is a stupid argument as a camera doesn't offer the same convenience with decent quality combo that a phone does. They're two different devices for different needs.

I realize, on the surface, 512GB seems like an awful lot of storage space but shooting high-resolution photos/videos (which is a huge selling point for this phone), you'll soon find available storage will dwindle down quickly. When was the last time you deleted photos and videos on your phone? Probably not in awhile or maybe never. As for me, I have photos and videos on my current phone that were taken 3 phones ago and backed up on my precious MicroSD card. And of course, life goes on and more pictures and videos will be taken, further making the space limitation much more apparent. So if you add up the photos/videos in your gallery, account for apps/games you install (which many are cumbersome and quickly rack up data and cache files) and then allocate space for future pictures and videos, etc. You'll quickly see how limiting and insufficient 512GB is. And many, because of the price difference, will probably settle on the 128GB or 256GB versions thinking that it'll be enough in the long-run until they're abruptly greeted with a "low storage space" notification with no external storage option to dump their files onto to free up internal. Furthermore, MicroSD cards are remarkably resilient. They can get stepped on, ran over, wet, left in extreme cold or heat and most of the time, the data is still intact. If you drop your phone and the circuit board cracks or gets water damage and shorts out the memory, say goodbye to your precious memories and other valuable data forever.... As you can see, there's some huge drawbacks and potential nightmares with not having a MicroSD slot.

I personally like the design. I think the purple/gold version is super tacky- the black and silver ones look nice. They have the tech to make QHD 120hz display but it's now only exclusive to Ultra series which is a huge letdown. My Galaxy S6 has higher resolution display than the Galaxy S21- ridiculous to think tech is going backwards in some aspects and yet is so much more expensive. No more SD slot. No more earbuds. No more charger. Samsung following Apple. If in the future I'm deciding between the iPhone and the Galaxy, I'll most likely end up going with the iPhone because at least their software support lasts a few years longer (iPhone 12 design is better than Galaxy S21 too in my opinion)- and that's saying a lot because I've never owned an iPhone or an iPad, but I have had the Galaxy S II (my very first smartphone), S3, Note II, S4, S5, S6, Note5, and S8. I also have the Galaxy Tab S3.

Samsung is resting on their laurels because there are no other Android competitors at the moment. I never hear Android vs iOS. I always hear Samsung vs Apple.

This is honestly time for the other android manufacturers to catch up and compete with Samsung again- unfortunately that's probably not going to happen. I miss HTC's amazing metal unibody design from their HTC One series. I think if LG made a high end flagship model of their Velvet series, it could be a hit. Google slapped its Pixel users across their faces when they removed original size unlimited Google Photos storage, so I'm still holding a grudge against them as my newest phone is the Pixel 4 XL and I was looking forward to unlimited photos in original resolution. Of course, as long as they keep QHD displays across all models of their flagship line, chargers, and maybe even earbuds. I've had so many upgrades and yet I'm still having to buy new earbuds and I don't have any extra chargers because the wires all ripped! It's just their excuse to promote their wireless chargers more.



For me, this is a Galaxy S twenty-flop. I'm gonna support the underdogs and hope for more competition within the smartphone realm in the future.
Support LG, support HTC, support Sony (if you can find one...), and any other Android manufacturers out there that are still alive. Promote competition as a consumer if you want better tech.

@RedBlueStar but 108 megapixels is just too much, most DSLR's have on average 20-24 megapixels, does that mean that this sensor is sharper or better? No. Sensor quality isn't just sharpness, and you could print 20mpx photos in a medium size frame without a problem (even from a phone, because other things matter more like dynamic range, color science, etc), watch Jared Polin's video on the iphone 12, he even printed photos from it and they look great! I'm not trying to say if Apple's cameras as better or Samsung's, or whatever, what I'm trying to say is that you can, and we always have, get away with a lower megapixel sensor and have great results, even better maybe, less megapixels=better low light like I told you for example.

I just bought a note 20 ultra. I've got a whitestone dome protector on the camera bump and screen, and a UAG monarch case on the phone. It does require a headphone adapter, but 25 bucks on amazon for a nice jsaux branded one that matches my phone case. The 120hz screen seems buttery smooth, didn't think a high refresh rate phone would be very important but it makes it seem SO much faster. Holding the device normally in the hand I can't even visually notice much of a difference if at all between the 1080p res and the 1440p. It supports microsd as well and tbh as long as the adapter holds up, while I don't like the lack of a headphone jack, as a musician and hi-fi music listener it isn't as bothersome as I'd expected. Just keep that thang on you haha. Unless Samsung changes their business philosophy though, this is likely the last samsung product I will buy. I like to pay for features, not pay a premium just to have features taken away.

Samsung's secret gameplan:

1. Make a great flagship
2. Price it at super premium for a month
3. THEN launch a dozen look-alikes in M, C, R, A, P etc. series with reduced specs
4. Alter the price of the flagship

So my confusion is as an average consumer why do they dump so much resource into a feature that is largely a gimmick? I spent $1000 on a phone with amazing back cameras that I can count on both hands the amount of times I 've used them but have a mediocre front camera that I use every day multiple times a day.

First off, I am quite disappointed by the lack of expandable storage. I had a Samsung Galaxy Note 5 which came with no expandable storage whatsoever. It was my single greatest regret. Whenever I went on longer vacations, my apps, music and photos VERY quickly filled up the 32 GB of storage. This is even before taking into account the FullHD 60 fps videos I wanted to film. Without a laptop to offload my photos to, I had to resort to Google Photos which butchered my video quality (which now isn't even an option since there's no longer unlimited storage). I know 32 GB is not the same as 128 - 512 but at the same time the camera on the Note 5 was 12MP and this is 108 MP. Videos are no longer FullHD but 4k etc.

Secondly, I find it quite annoying that there are no included charger. Look, I have a charger at home that does its job quite well but then I'm 100% sure the manual will specify "You should only used approved SAMSUNG charging equipment for this terminal" which I find to be total BS (this is pure speculation). What Apple set as a precedent wasn't brave and environmentally-friendly, it was greedy, wasteful (think of all the packaging) and generally just a jackass move; something I had hoped the best of the best wouldn't stoop to. And the cost of the charger wasn't even subtracted from the price of the phone. I would very much understand if the Ultra would have been 1100 USD but...

Finally, the lack of headphone jack... I have bluetooth headphones so that isn't as much of an issue but when I want to connect it to my sound system...

So even though I was looking forward to the new line-up and had saved up money to buy; I will be skipping this generation or going for another phone.

The only reason I bought the S20 Ultra was +100x zoom, 100 mp camera and 5g.  None of these worked and I had constant focus problems. The 100x zoom was utterly worthless, grainy and looked like the Pic was drawn with a crayon. You lose all definition above 12 mp so even though you can zoom 30x, 40x or more...editing or enlarging to print simply doesn't work.  When will they wake up and realize the absolute must have is battery life?  5000 mah should be minimum. You can keep the 100x zoom which would also eliminate the brick of a camera bump... Keep your 100 mp camera and give me real 24 mp, which would equal most slr cameras. Bring back rear fingerprint scan.  The screen reader is a pain. Get rid of the facial recognition, iris scan.  Completely unnecessary for 99% of users. Stop making everything so friggin complicated and just make a 5G phone with 7500 mah battery, fast charge, 4k, 12/24 mp camera and lose the effing bloatware.  I will happily pay $500 more for that phone.  Charge me $1500...I don't care. Just give me what I want for a change...

@beclops I didn't say anyone here was being a snob, but it seems as though many Apple users are. If you like Apple products then that's fine but I always like to get what's best.

@yo boi Steven Like I said, specs don't matter when you have integration. I don't really care if my phone has less RAM if it feels good, and at the other end, just because your phone has 12Gb of RAM it doesn't mean your OS/Software will be efficiently using it. As far as I'm concerned, nobody here was being a "snob" until you came in implying people are sheep because they buy things they enjoy. Honestly who cares what type of slab of glass and metal is in another person's pocket, it's dumb to let it preoccupy you like this.

@beclops "Specs don't matter" Well, actually they do. Sure they're not everything but it's pretty sickening to see some of the stuff that Apple cheaps out on. For example ram is sufficiently lower than it's Android counterparts. Their flagships are just now getting 6gb of ram. Things such as display are also having corners cut, still no 120 hz display? Come on Apple. I just want the phone that's best and at the moment it's not an Apple. Samsung has had everything nailed from their display, to their OS, to their camera for years on end and although I'm not too impressed with this years lineup of phones, they still have my upmost respect. I know Apple makes good products but they're not the best and I'm sick of Apple snobs looking down on Android users like their some kind of second class citizen even when the Android is the better phone.

@yo boi Steven Specs don't matter. As a software dev, what tends to matter more is integration and theirs is better than essentially anything out there. Take a look at the M1 chip on their new MacBooks, they're unreal even though on paper the specs aren't stellar.
@beclops Most Apple sheep just buy any shit that apple craps out and puts in a box. They don‚Äôt know what specs are.
